item.title: Hamas Accepts US Proposal On Talks Over Releasing Israeli Hostages: Report
item.description: Hamas has accepted a US proposal to begin talks on releasing Israeli hostages, including soldiers and men, 16 days after the first phase of an agreement aimed at ending the Gaza war, a senior Hamas source told Reuters on Saturday.

item.title: After Crushing Poll Defeat, UK's Conservatives Scrambling To Rebuild
item.description: Britain's Conservative Party, thrashed by Labour at the general election, on Saturday faced the task of rebuilding as leading right wingers warned it could face extinction unless it starts listening to its core voters.

item.title: Meghan McCain asked to shut up on X as her Biden-bashing continues: 'Your father...'
item.description: Meghan McCain, daughter of former senator late John McCain was asked to shut up on X Saturday as she continued her tirade against Joe Biden and the Biden family. Social media users shared the old photo of Joe Biden comforting Meghan when her father was suffering from brain cancer. "Did Meghan say her father was cognitively incapable? No, she didn't," a user wrote.

item.title: ‘Blue wall’ of Tory seats collapsed because of green issues, say Greenpeace
item.description:
Polling shows voters in south of England switched because of Conservative inaction on polluted rivers and beaches

The sewage crisis was a significant factor in the Tories’ losing support in the “blue wall” in the south of England, electoral polling suggests.

Seven out of 10 voters supported legal measures to eliminate sewage spills in ecologically sensitive areas by 2030, according to polling conducted for Greenpeace by Survation just before the election. Less than a third of voters thought the Conservatives were right to weaken their commitments on the climate crisis and the environment.

Continue reading...

item.title: David Lammy: ‘Britain has to start reconnecting with a dangerous, divided world’
item.description:
New foreign secretary says resetting UK relations with EU is a particular priority as he travels to Germany, Poland and Sweden, then the US

• David Lammy faces a world in turmoil: five key concerns for foreign secretary

Britain must reconnect with the rest of the world with major resets in climate change policy, and in the country’s relationships with Europe and with the global south, foreign secretary David Lammy has said in an interview with the Guardian before his first international trip.

Lammy has taken up his position, one of the four great offices of state, at a time of immense foreign policy challenges, from two major wars to global inertia about tackling a warming planet.

Continue reading...

item.title: David Lammy faces a world in turmoil: five key concerns for foreign secretary
item.description:
Challenges include two wars and global inertia on the climate crisis as hard-right populists from France to the US flex their muscles

• David Lammy: ‘Britain has to start reconnecting with a dangerous, divided world’

More than two years after Russia invaded Ukraine, the conflict drags on. Ukrainian forces are depleted and they need foreign weapons. Support for Ukraine crosses most party lines in Europe, but if Donald Trump wins the US election and cuts or limits the flow of arms, Europe may struggle to fill the gap. Lammy will want to shore up public support, bolster European collaboration, and map out what resources the continent can collectively offer Ukraine if the US steps back.

Continue reading...
